prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO(1-0) NGC 2623
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing NGC 2623, a merger remnant, in 13CO(1-0) at a resolution of 2". The ACA+TP are not required as 13CO is usually much more compact than 12CO. Only one pointing is necessary to encompass the CO emission.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
13CO(1-0) AND C18O SENSITIVITY: We use the CARMA 13CO(1-0) observations (Sliwa et al. in prep.) to estimate the required sensitivity. The peak intensity of 13CO(1-0) is roughly 5 mJy/beam in a 2" beam; therefore, for a ~13 sigma detection at 30km/s, we require a sensitivity of 0.38mJy per channel. If we assume that 13CO/C18O ~5, a value we find for the LIRG VV114, we should detect the C18O line at ~4sigma level at 60km/s channel width. Only ALMA is able to give us a decent signal-to-noise ratio for these weak lines.
BANDWIDTH: NGC 2623 has a very broad CO line width; therefore, 30 km/s will still give us a good line measurement. Increasing the bandwidth also decreases the integration time needed.

DATA RATE: We use a spectral averaging factor of 4 to lower the data rate. This slightly reduced the spectral resolution to ~6 km/s. We do not require the finest spectral resolution as we do not expect to detect the spectral lines at ~1km/s.
BANDWIDTH: We use four wide bandwidth spectral windows (1.875 GHz each) with a fine spectral resolution. The line width of CO in NGC 2623 is quite wide (290 km/s); therefore a broad spectral window is required to ensure we observe the entire line profile and enough line-free channels to subtract the continuum.
SPECTRAL WINDOW PLACEMENT: We place spectral windows near spectral lines that may be detected within the integration time. Other windows will be used to measure the continuum; however, we still use a fine spectral resolution for these windows as there may be unexpected spectral lines.
One spectral window is placed near 13CO(1-0), 13CN N=1-0, CS J=2-1 and the last window will be used from continuum measurements.

RESOLUTION: We request a resolution of 2" in order to match the coarsest resolution of the Submillimeter Array (SMA) observations of Wilson et al.(2008).
LARGEST ANGULAR SCALE: The SMA was able to recover all the flux of the 12CO(2-1) and (3-2) lines when compared to single dish observations. Using the shortest baseline of the SMA data, we determine that the largest angular scale is less than 10". When we flag several of the shortest baselines, we find that below an angular scale of 5", we start to encounter the missing flux problem; therefore, we do not need the ACA and TP for NGC 2623.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO(2-1) NGC 2623
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing NGC 2623 in 13CO(2-1) in 1 pointing. The ACA+TP are not required as 13CO is usually more compact than 12CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
13CO(2-1) SENSITIVITY: We use the 12CO(2-1) Submillmeter Array (SMA) map of Wilson et al. (2008) to estimate the sensitivity required for 13CO(2-1). The peak intensity of the 12CO(2-1) is 500 mJy/beam at a resolution of ~2". Assuming a 12CO/13CO line ratio of 50, we estimate the peak intensity of 13CO(2-1) to be 10mJy/beam. We, therefore, require a sensitivity of 0.4mJy, for a 25 sigma detection at 30 km/s channel width. The required sensitivity is ~30 times better than the sensitivity of the SMA map of Wilson et al. (2008) where there was no 13CO(2-1) detection. If the C18O(2-1) line is ~5 times weaker, then at 30 km/s, we should detect the line at a 5sigma level.
CONTINUUM SENSITIVITY: The given continuum peak flux is measured in the SMA map of Wilson et al. (2008).

See the technical justification for the 13CO(1-0) NGC 2623 science goal.
SPECTRAL WINDOW PLACEMENT: One spectral window is placed near 13CO(2-1), C18O(2-1) and the remaining two windows will be used for continuum measurements. We still require a fine spectral resolution in case we detect any unexpected spectral lines.
See the technical justification of the 13CO(1-0) NGC 2623 science goal.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13CO(1-0) Arp 240
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We are observing the merger Arp 240 (NGC 5257/58), in 13CO(1-0). We require 2 pointings, one on each galaxy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
13CO(1-0) SENSITIVITY: We use the 12CO(1-0) observations of Iono et al. (2005) to estimate the peak flux of 13CO(1-0). The peak flux in the north-western galaxy (NGC 5257), where the weakest CO emission is seen, is 140 mJy within a 4.8". Assuming that the emission is uniform and adopting a 12CO/13CO line ratio of 30 (not unreasonable for an early merger stage; Aalto et al. 1992), we estimate a 13CO(1-0) peak intensity of 2 mJy per 1.6" beam. Therefore, we require a sensitivity of 0.45 mJy for a ~4.5 sigma detection per 50 km/s channel width.
BANDWIDTH: The line width of Arp 240 is quite wide, therefore, we can increase the channel width in order to decrease the integration time since the 13CO lines are extremely weak in Arp 240. With a 50 km/s channel width, we will still have enough spectral resolution elements for a good line observation.
We use a similar set as for NGC 2623 (see technical justification for 13CO(1-0) NGC 2623).

RESOLUTION: We request an angular resolution of 1.6" to match the same spatial resolution of the NGC 2623 observations (~800pc).
LARGEST ANGULAR SCALE: We do not require ACA+TP observations for 13CO as it usually is emitted from more compact regions than 12CO.
IMAGING: We require 2 pointings, one on each galaxy.

13CO(2-1) SENSITIVITY: We use the 12CO(2-1) Submillimeter Array(SMA) map of Wilson et al. (2008) to estimate the sensitivity required to detect 13CO(2-1). The weakest peak flux of 12CO(2-1) in Arp 240 is 0.170 Jy/beam at a resolution of 3.1". Assuming that the emission is uniform and adopting a 12CO/13CO line ratio of 30 (not unreasonable for an early merger stage; Aalto et al. 1992), we estimate a 13CO(2-1) peak intensity of 1.5 mJy per 1.6" beam. Therefore, we require a sensitivity of 0.375 mJy for a 4sigma detection per 50 km/s channel width. The requested sensitivity is over 300 times better than the SMA map of Wilson et al. (2008), which had no detection of the 13CO(2-1) line at a coarser resolution.
CONTINUUM: The given continuum peak flux is measured from the SMA map of Wilson et al. (2008) adjusted for 1.6" beam size assuming uniform emission.
See the technical justification of the 13CO(2-1) NGC 2623 science goal.

RESOLUTION AND LARGEST ANGULAR SCALE: See the technical justification for the 13CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.
IMAGING: We image Arp 240 in a mosaic to map the same regions as the SMA observations of Wilson et al. (2008). We place rectangular boxes on each galaxy (NGC 5257 and NGC 5258) that cover the CO(2-1) emission.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(1-0) Arp 240
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will observe Arp 240 (NGC 5257/8) in 12CO J=1-0. The observations will require 2 pointints, one on each galaxy in this merger.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
12CO(1-0) SENSITIVITY: We use the CO(1-0) observations of Iono et al. (2005) to estimate the peak intensity in Arp 240. The northern galaxy has the weakest CO emission at ~140 Jy km/s within a beam of 4.8". The FWHM of the line is 250 km/s; therefore the peak is 560 mJy at 4.8". Assuming the emission is uniform, in a 1.6" beam, we estimate the peak to be 60 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 2 mJy giving us at least a 30sigma detection at 10 km/s in Arp 240. This sensitivity is ~12 times better than Iono et al. (2005).
BANDWIDTH: The 12CO lines are very bright in Arp 240; therefore, we can afford to detect the lines at a 10km/s channel width. The line width of Arp 240 is quite broad and a 10km/s channel width will give ample spectral resolution elements for a good line measurement.

BANDWIDTH: The line width of CO in Arp 240 is quite broad (250 km/s); therefore, a broad bandwidth spectral window is needed to observe the entire line and enough line-free channels for continuum subtraction. A fine spectral resolution is needed to achieve good line measurements.
SPECTRAL WINDOW PLACEMENT: One spectral window is placed near CO(1-0), CN (1-0) and the remaining two spectral windows will be used for continuum measurements.

RESOLUTION: See technical justification for 13CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.
LARGEST ANGULAR SCALE: The Submillimeter Array (SMA) observations of Wilson et al. (2008) showed that roughly 40% of the CO flux is missing in the 12CO(3-2) observations of Arp 240. The largest angular scale quoted in the OT is roughly the extent of the 12CO (2-1) emission seen in the SMA map. We require the ACA to recover the missing flux in this system.
IMAGING: We require 2 pointings, one on each galaxy.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 12CO(2-1) Arp 240
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will observe Arp 240 (NGC 5257/8) in 12CO J=2-1. The observations will require 3 pointings to encompass the molecular gas emission. There will be 2 pointings on the south-eastern galaxy and 1 on the north-western galaxy.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
12CO(2-1) SENSITIVITY: The weakest CO(2-1) emission in Arp 240 comes from the northern galaxy (Wilson et al. 2008). The peak intensity in the northern galaxy is 170 mJy in a 3.1" beam. Assuming the emission is uniform, in a 1.6" beam, the peak intensity is estimated to be 45 mJy. We request a sensitivity of 3 mJy to detect the CO(2-1) line at a 15sigma level in a 10km/s channel width.
CONTINUUM: The continuum peak flux given in the OT is measured from the SMA map of Wilson et al. (2008) adjusted for a 1.6" beam size assuming uniform emission.
BANDWIDTH: See technical justification for 12CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.

See the technical justification for 12CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.
SPECTRAL WINDOW PLACEMENT: We place one spectral window near 12CO(2-1), another near CS (5-4), another near Halpha(30) and the remaining window will be used for continuum measurements.

RESOLUTION AND LARGEST ANGULAR SCALE: See technical justification for 12CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.
IMAGING: See technical justification for 13CO(2-1) Arp 240 science goal.

12CO(3-2) SENSITIVITY: The weakest emission in Arp 240 comes from the north-western galaxy (NGC 5257). Using the Submillimeter Array observations of Wilson et al. (2008), the peak flux in NGC 5257 is 0.35 Jy in a 3.4" beam. Assuming uniform emission across the galaxy, we estimate the peak flux to be 75 mJy in a 1.6" beam. We request a sensitivity of 5 mJy giving us a 15 sigma detection in NGC 5257 per 10km/s channel width. The requested sensitivity is 35 times better than the observations of Wilson et al. (2008), which marginally detected CO(3-2).
CONTINUUM: The continuum peak flux given in the OT is measured by Wilson et al. (2008) adjusted for a 1.6" beam size assuming uniform emission.
BANDWIDTH: See technical justification for 12CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.

BANDWIDTH: See the technical justification for 12CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.
SPECTRAL WINDOW PLACEMENT: We place one spectral window near 12CO(3-2), another near HCO+(4-3) and the remaining windows will be used for continuum measurements.

RESOLUTION AND LARGEST ANGULAR SCALE: See the technical justification of the 12CO(1-0) Arp 240 science goal.
IMAGING: See the technical justification of 13CO(2-1) Arp 240 science goal.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The galaxy merger process is still not well understood and more observational constraints are necessary to improve numerical simulations. We propose to observed two mergers (NGC 2623 and Arp 240) at opposite ends of the merger process in several 12CO and 13CO transitions. Combining the proposed observations with existing CO data, we will perform a radiative transfer analysis to constrain the physical conditions of the molecular gas at each merger stage. We will compare the physical conditions with other mergers at different stages to look for trends in the molecular gas properties, CO-to-H2 conversion factor and the [12CO]/[13CO] abundace ratio with merger stage.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University
